title: 3. Obtaining Approvals
text:
Obtaining necessary approvals is essential for beginning the data collection process. Since approval requirements vary by country, this step provides a list of common approvals. The examples provided are from previous implementations, but GEPD’s implementation team should always meet country-specific regulatory needs.
Certain approvals are necessary to ensure ethical standards are met, particularly when the data collection involves sensitive activities such as interviewing and assessing children, as well as conducting classroom observations. These approvals safeguard the rights and well-being of participants, especially minors.
Sample of Types of Approvals that might be needed:

Ethical Approval - (if applicable).
Approvals requested from the National Statistics Agency - (if applicable).

The Approvals topic can be approached during the Initial Meeting, where the specific approvals required in the country through for the data collection can be clarified in the discussions with government officials.
To comprehensively address these requirements, the local team must collaborate closely with the Survey Firm. In most implementations, it is the Survey Firm that bears the primary responsibility for securing all necessary approvals, ensuring that the data collection process adheres to both local and international ethical guidelines.

title: 2. Selecting Sample
text:
The Global Education Policy Dashboard (GEPD) uses a two-stage random sampling method for collecting representative and quality data. Initially, schools are selected through a stratified sampling based on urban/rural classification and, if needed, geographical regions. This step guarantees a diverse and accurate representation of the nation’s schools. The second stage involves randomly selecting teachers and students from these schools for interviews and assessments.

School SamplingPublic Officials Sampling




The Sampling Tool can only be used when the Country share the Country’s List of Schools file, that can also be downloaded here School List - this is the same list previously discussed with country at the substep 1.4 of Confirming Country’s Participation. Such list contains the following columns, to be populated:

Name of School: Official name of the educational institution.
Region: Geographical region where the school is located.
District: Administrative district of the school’s location.
City: City or town where the school is situated.
Geographic Location: School’s specific geographical coordinates.
Urban or Rural Indicator: Classification as urban or rural.
Type of School: Category or kind of school (e.g., primary).
Type of Property: Ownership status of the school building.
Does the school have a second shift? Yes/No: Indicator of dual-shift system.
1st Grade Total Number of Students: Total students in 1st grade.
2nd Grade Total Number of Students: Total students in 2nd grade.
3rd Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 3rd grade.
th Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 4th grade.
5th Grade Total Number of Students: Total students in 5th grade.
6th Grade Total Number of Students: Total students in 6th grade.
1st Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 1st grade.
2nd Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 2nd grade.
3rd Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 3rd grade.
4th Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 4th grade.
5th Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 5th grade.
6th Grade Total Number of Teachers: Total teachers for 6th grade.




The rules for running the random stratification when sampling are:

Sample size: GEPD common sample size is of 200 to 300 schools;
Stratification: GEPD uses the rural/urban classification as a Strata when sampling. The region column is optional, but including it can influence the overall sample size
Minimum of students: to qualify as a valid sample school, each school must have a minimum of three (3) students in both 1st and 4th grades.





Upload your excel or csv file containing the list of schools
Choose the sample size of schools (from 200 to 300 sample size)
Choose one or two columns that you want to use for stratification
Run the sampling!
Visualize the schools selected
Download your file containing the schools sampled
Document the steps of your sampling process
Reach out to the Central Team as needed



This Sampling Tool was created to assist you during the Sampling Process of GEPD’s Implementation. You can also access the source code used to generate the stratified sample by downloading it: Download Sampling R Code



In the GEPD implementation, the sampling of public officials involves selecting 200 public education officials, focusing on personnel from both central and regional/district offices of the Ministry of Education. The sampling utilizes a cluster strategy. However, most commonly, instead of receiving a direct list of public officials, GEPD is typically provided with a list of regional and district public office locations.
Based on this, 10 regional offices are randomly selected from the regions corresponding to the school survey. In each region, one district office is chosen. Within these offices, the sampling includes 7 officials: the head of the office, the HR director, and five randomly chosen officials from finance and planning.
The federal level sampling is conducted in collaboration with the Ministry of Education, focusing on key offices, where the director and a random selection of officials are interviewed. This stratified approach ensures comprehensive coverage from school to district, regional, and central offices.



Receive Office Locations List
Select Regional Offices: randomly choose 10 regional offices from the provided list, ensuring they align with the regions where schools were surveyed.
Choose District Offices: In each selected region, randomly pick one district office
Sample Officials in Offices:

In each regional/district office, randomly select 7 officials, including the office head, HR director, and five officials from finance and planning.
At the federal level, work with the Ministry of Education to identify relevant offices. Interview the office director and a random number of staff members.

Document the sampling process

title: 6. Training Enumerators and Piloting the Project
1. Confirming Country’s Participation
text:
Step 1’s primary goal is to secure a country’s participation in the Global Education Policy Dashboard (GEPD). This process begins with identifying a potential need for the GEPD in a country and then arranging and conducting an initial meeting to present the Dashboard.
A follow-up email is sent post-meeting to confirm participation and outline the next steps and most immediate actions required. Finally, once participation is confirmed, the TTL coordinates communication accordingly, guaranteeing the necessary information exchange.

text:

title: 1. Confirming Country’s Participation
text:
Step-by-step:

1.1 - Opportunity Window: Identifying a need for the Dashboard
At this moment, the task is to pinpoint a specific need within a country that the GEPD can effectively address. This process might involve analyzing situations where the Dashboard can serve as a potent solution. These needs can be identified proactively by investigating the country’s education policy landscape or in response to a direct request from the country. The goal is to establish the GEPD as a fitting tool that aligns with the country’s educational objectives and challenges.





1.2 - Requesting an Initial Meeting
In this phase, the focus shifts to the TTL arranging an initial meeting with key stakeholders in the potential counterpart country. This meeting is planned to last 60-90 minutes, and is intended to delve deeper into the Dashboard’s capabilities and relevance to the country’s needs. Preparation for this meeting involves sending a well-crafted introductory email to the country’s representatives, accompanied by essential GEPD’s resources and the link for GEPD’s Website. These documents should provide more details on the Dashboard, illustrating its capacity to meet the country’s specific data requirements.
1.2.1 - RESOURCES AVAILABLE:

Implementation Brief: English | French | Spanish | Arabic | Portuguese
Reference Guide: English | French | Spanish | Arabic | Portuguese
Sample Email: English | French | Spanish | Arabic | Portuguese






1.3 - Conducting the Meeting
Once the initial meeting is set, the TTL prepares to lead the discussion. The suggested agenda for the meeting is for it to start with a 20-minute presentation on the GEPD, utilizing the provided sample presentation, which needs to be tailored for the country in question. The presentation aims to give a comprehensive overview of the Dashboard’s functionality and benefits. Following the presentation, the TTL dedicates the remaining time to address various key aspects, such as:

Responding to questions about the project’s scope, objectives, and potential impact.
Discussing the specifics of the implementation process.
Detailing the requirements from the country:

Appointing a focal point;
Providing necessary information for sampling;
Understanding the required approvals documents.

Aiming to confirm the country’s participation in the GEPD

1.3.1 - RESOURCES AVAILABLE:

Sample Presentation: English | French | Spanish | Arabic | Portuguese
Meeting’s FAQ: English | French | Spanish | Arabic | Portuguese






1.4 - Next Steps Email (following-up after Initial Meeting)
After the initial meeting, the following action is to send a comprehensive follow-up email to the country’s representatives. This email should be structured to provide clarity and direction, ensuring the country’s representatives are fully informed of the requirements and upcoming phases in the GEPD implementation process. Its essential purposes are:

Reiteration and Documentation: It includes the presentation delivered during the meeting as an attachment, serving as a reference point and reinforcing the discussed topics.
Confirmation of Participation: If the country’s participation was confirmed during the meeting, the email will formally acknowledge this and express appreciation for the commitment.
Outlining Next Steps: Importantly, the email will detail the subsequent steps required to move the GEPD project forward. This includes:

Creating a project timeline, providing a clear schedule of activities and milestones.
Requesting sample data for the schools and public officials survey, guided by the attached Excel table format.
Establishing contact with the focal point to facilitate data collection and follow-up communications.
Provide the counterpart with all the actions needed from their side


1.4.1 - RESOURCES AVAILABLE:

Next Steps Sample Email: English | French | Spanish | Arabic | Portuguese
School Information: English | French | Spanish | Arabic | Portuguese






1.5 - Establishing Channels of Communication
Once the country’s participation is confirmed and the first communications starts to happen, the TTL’s role shifts towards maintaining momentum and ensuring effective communication. The primary focus at this stage involves two critical aspects:

Refining the Project Timeline: The TTL must work closely with the country’s team to develop a comprehensive timeline for the GEPD implementation. This timeline should outline all key phases, milestones, and deadlines, providing a clear roadmap for the project.
Facilitating Information and Data Exchange: Ongoing interaction between the TTL and the country’s team is essential. The TTL will coordinate the exchange of necessary information and data, ensuring that both sides have what they need for successful implementation. This exchange is crucial for tailoring the GEPD to the country’s specific needs.

The TTL should approach this phase with a focus on clear, consistent communication and collaboration. Keeping the lines of communication open will ensure that any challenges or questions are promptly addressed, and the project stays on track.

title: 4. Procuring Survey Firm
text:
Survey firms are selected through competitive bidding - a procurement process, aligned with the Bank standards that spans about eight weeks. The process begins with drafting an Expression of Interest (EOI) letter and Terms of Reference (TOR). Once these documents are ready, the local team initiates the competitive procurement process at the Bank’s RFX Platform.


1. Ensure RFX’s Accreditation

Confirm that you or someone in the team - with powers to have it - have the necessary RFX accreditation to use the World Bank’s procurement platform. This is essential for initiating and managing the procurement process.
RFX’s Platform has a lot of resources available teaching how to be properly used. In an extra section that can be found at the bottom of this page we share some of them.

2. Draft the Expression of Interest (EOI)

Create an EOI document, clearly outlining the requirements and expectations for the survey firm. Ensure the EOI is concise yet comprehensive.

Resource Available: Download Sample EOI
3. Draft the Terms of Reference (ToR)

Prepare the ToR, detailing the scope of work, responsibilities, and qualifications needed from the survey firm. A sample for you to edit is provided below, just ensure that the ToR aligns with GEPD’s project goals.

Resource Available: Download Sample ToR
4. Launch the EOI

Publish the EOI on the Bank’s procurement platform, making it available for potential firms to apply. Set a reasonable deadline for submissions, typically 2-3 weeks so they can submit their proposals.

5. Score Matching received Proposals & Identifying Winning Firm

After the EOI deadline, review all submissions and shortlist firms based on their initial proposals. Proposals will then be scored on how well they meet the technical requirements outlined in the ToR. When technical scores are submitted and locked, then the financial proposals can be open (the system will generate score automatically for financials). Based on that, winning firm is identified.
After identifying the winner, allow 1-2 weeks for contract to be signed / processed. After that make sure to arrange a kickoff meeting with the winning Survey Firm - a moment of first contact after Procurement Process is over.




Click here to access it: RFX’s Platform

title: 5. Preparing Field Work
text:
Step 5 focuses on preparing the field work. This step begins with a detailed onboarding email for the selected survey firm, ensuring they are well-informed and equipped with all necessary resources. The email should also contain an invitation for a kick-off meeting to align everyone’s understanding of the project scope, timeline, and specific roles.
This step ensures that both the Task Team Leader (TTL) and the survey firm are fully prepared to execute the field work efficiently, addressing any potential questions and closely supervising the firm’s preparations to ensure adherence to the GEPD’s project standards.


1. Email for Onboarding the Survey Firm:
The onboarding email to the survey firm marks the beginning of Step 5. It formally welcomes the firm and provides essential information and resources for the project. The email - a sample of it can be downloaded below too - should include attached the following documents:

School Survey Instrument:Download
Manual of the School Survey:Download
Step-by-step Guide for the School Survey:Download
Survey of Public Officials Instrument:Download
Manual of the Survey of Public Officials:Download
Step-by-step Guide for the Survey of Public Officials:Download
Recordings of Previous Survey Firm’s Training:Download

In addition, the email outlines the immediate steps for the firm, which include:

Adapting instruments to the Country of implementation’s reality
Planning on translations of the Instruments - if applicable
Inviting the Firm to a kick-off meeting.

2. Kick-off Meeting with the Firm
The kick-off meeting, is the space for the TTL to ensure that the project’s scope, timeline, and roles are all clear for the survey firm. It’s the moment to go through the contract details, including deliverables and quality standards, so addressing initial questions and setting clear expectations are key. The TTL should highlight critical milestones and discuss immediate preparatory steps.
As a resource, this FAQ of potential questions might prove useful: Download Kick-off Meeting FAQ
3. Supervising the Preparations of the Firm
The final step of Preparing the Field Work concerns the TTL responsibility of supervising the survey firm’s preparations, ensuring they meet GEPD standards and adhere to project timelines. This role might involve:

Ensuring the Survey Firm have access to all necessary materials
Overseeing the Survey Firm’s training process and pre-tests of the tools
Overseeing the instrument adaptation, translations and elaboration of the field protocols
Addressing the Survey Firm questions about the survey methodologies

The TTL must also confirm that logistical plans for field work are finalized. Regular check-ins are key for assessing the firm’s progress and addressing potential issues promptly.

title: The Implementation Package
text:
After thirteen implementations of the Global Education Policy Dashboard, all of which happened with a close partnership with regional teams, the central team is excited to present this Implementation Package. It is a comprehensive toolkit that aids in deploying the GEPD’s innovative instruments – the School Survey, Policy Survey, and Survey of Public Officials – with efficiency and effectiveness. It aims to equip local teams with step-by-step guides, practical tools, and all necessary resources for seamless data collection and analysis.
The goal of the Package is to empower local teams with the means to illuminate the often-unseen drivers of learning outcomes, turning insights into actionable strategies for educational advancement. It gives structured guidance throughout the entire process of school visits, classroom observations, and all the moments of engaging with educational stakeholders, ensuring that the GEPD can be implemented with precision and minimal complexity.



Step-by-step GEPD Implementation

title: Global Education Policy Dashboard
text:
Addressing the Learning Crisis
Policymakers in low - and middle - income countries who are working to improve student learning often find themselves flying blind. They see the budget that goes into education and (sometimes) the learning that students come out with, but they lack information on many of the crucial factors in between—the practices, policies, and politics—that drive those learning outcomes. The Global Education Policy Dashboard (GEPD) shines a light on those hidden drivers. To tackle the learning crisis, achieving and sustaining learning gains at scale, countries need to know where they stand on all three of these dimensions—practices (or service delivery), policies, and politics.

title: Global Education Policy Dashboard
text:
The Dashboard
The Global Education Policy Dashboard (GEPD), developed by the World Bank’s Education Global Practice, can help countries reduce Learning Poverty. This tool offers a strong basis for identifying priorities for investment and policy reforms that are suited to each country context. It does so by (1) highlighting gaps between what the evidence suggests is effective in promoting learning and what is happening in practice in each system; and (2) allowing governments to track progress as they take action to close those gaps. The GEPD has been implemented in seven education systems and preparation is ongoing in eight more with expected completion by the end of 2024.
GEPD collects new data in each country using three new instruments: a School Survey, a Policy Survey, and a Survey of Public Officials. Data collection involves school visits, classroom observations, legislative reviews, teacher and student assessments, and interviews with teachers, principals, and public officials. A major objective of the GEPD project was to develop focused, cost-effective instruments and data-collection procedures, so that the dashboard can be inexpensive enough to be applied (and re-applied) in many countries.
